Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Species of a new generation -- Integration of massively parallel sequencing, morphological, and niche modeling data for species discovery and delimitation.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Species represent the fundamental units of evolutionary and ecological studies, yet their nature and how best to circumscribe them remain controversial. The southeastern US Wild Gingers (Asarum subgenus Heterotropa) are a highly variable group of plants that have long been problematic in their species boundaries, as well as being poorly known with respect to reproductive biology. This project develops a novel quantitative approach to delimiting species and characterizing reproductive biology by integrating data from sophisticated morphological analysis, climatic variables, geography, cutting-edge DNA analysis, and pollinator identity that can serve as a model for future work.

The appreciation, management, and conservation of biodiversity are greatly hindered by ill-defined species boundaries, and this project develops a powerful new tool for investigators of any biological system. Collections made for the study will be publicly available to other investigators. An online database will serve as an identification resource for ecologists, land managers, and amateur botanists who encounter SE US Wild Gingers. This project will support the research and training of a doctoral student, and the public at large will benefit through exhibits at the annual Ohio State University Museum of Biological Diversity Open House, public lectures, and a laboratory module to be designed for use in introductory biology courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is often very surprising to those outside the biological sciences that no community consensus exists for what constitutes a species or how one goes about identifying such an entity. As DNA sequencing has become more refined and cost-effective, its use has become the primary focus of many systematists working to both discover and circumscribe species in a way which most closely approximates natural relationships and takes into consideration their evolutionary relationships. This reliance on DNA data continues to persist despite calls for integrative taxonomy. Ideally, species circumscription would consider the totality of an organism’s life history, its ecological associations, and its physical and genetic characteristics. A primary outcome of this research is the integration of DNA sequencing data from thousands of regions across the genome, mathematical descriptions of flower shape, and environmental data contained in climatic datasets to evaluate species boundaries in a plant group of conservation concern that is endemic to the southeastern United States. Our work shows that the current taxonomic treatment of this group underestimates the number of Asarum species in the southern Appalachians, which leaves several narrow endemics unrecognized. An additional outcome of this research is a review and reevaluation of a commonly used species concept, which resulted in a combining of the Ecological and Evolutionary Species Concepts. Both our concept and the empirical framework used in study are applicable to nearly any group of organisms.

 DNA sequencing used for this study yielded an unexpected outcome, which is that the structure, length, and gene order of the typically highly stable chloroplast genome of the lineage of plants to which Asarum belongs.  These genomes represent the first rearranged, yet functional, chloroplast genomes from the magnoliids, a group of flowering plants which to date is characterized by unrearranged chloroplast genomes. The incremental differences observed between the genomes of our study species have provided a rare glimpse into the mutations that can proceed and predispose genome destabilization and lead to genetic rearrangements, and perhaps most importantly, unexpected gene deletions. These results are the first to show that chloroplast genomes of photosynthetic species of the Magnoliids can become destabilized in like fashion to those reported from the other distantly related groups of flowering plants, and allows us to better understand molecular predispositions to genomic change.

This study significantly improved training and mentorship opportunities for one Ph.D. student, and contributed to the foundation of another Ph.D. student’s project. Three undergraduates from two institutions were trained in bioinformatics, massively parallelized DNA sequencing, and phylogenetic methods. The methodologies used in this study will be incorporated into future lab sections associated with courses in at The Ohio State University, including Integrative Biology, ensuring that undergraduate students have the experience and skills necessary to conduct and evaluate scientific research. Public scientific literacy will be improved through the incorporation of the results of this research into a future OSU Museum of Biological Diversity Open House. In regards to biological infrastructure, more than 1,000 plant specimens from more than a dozen university and museum collections have received expert identifications, and hundreds of field-preserved flower collections for future identification have been made. All DNA sequences and assembled genomes will be deposited with NCBI and freely available to researchers world-wide upon publication of this research. Additionally, a revised dichotomous identification key for Asarum species endemic to the southeastern US has been produced, and a version augmented with proprietary, high-resolution photographs will be available on the Ohio State University Herbarium webpage in the near future.
